posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: Title says it all. From file organization to parts libraries to assemble construction, what does clean CAD look like to you? What practices do you do (both on your team and professionally) to produce clean CAD?

link_counts.title: Does Clean CAD Matter in FRC?

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked:
Say it with me, kids:

Fully define your sketches

posts.name: Roger Moore
posts.cooked: And no, fixing the the entire sketch does not count.

posts.name: Frank Lima
posts.cooked:
The feature tree needs to tell a story. If you roll back the feature tree and look at each sketch and feature in order you should be able to understand what the designer was thinking when creating the part. CAD is as much a communication tool as a design tool.

Good Sketches → Easy to read Features → Easy to Edit/Modify parts → Faster iterations → Better Robots

ps. ALWAYS include fasteners

posts.name: Clayton Ramsey
posts.cooked:
Andrew_L:

Fully define your sketches

Like this?

image 1791×1043 108 KB

image 1791×1043 108 KB

image 1791×1043 108 KB

image 1816×1342 152 KB

image 1816×1342 152 KB

image 1816×1342 152 KB

also, we cannot forget the classic :

image 787×768 121 KB

image 787×768 121 KB

image 787×768 121 KB

For a more serious reply:

Separate degrees of freedom should (almost) always mean separate assemblies, such as the first stage of an elevator being a complete assembly on its own, independent of the second stage.

Top-level assemblies (typically the robot, and sometimes individual mechanisms) shouldn’t have individual parts in them, only assemblies. There are a few exceptions, such as pneumatics which mate to two different assemblies.

Dimensions should show clear intent - no magic numbers! Metric dimensions should have a dual dimension as well to show why they are the way they are.

If parts have lines of symmetry, they should be aligned with the origin planes. This is probably the #1 beginner CAD smell.

Materials should always be set correctly, or at least to a best guess, and part color should generally reflect those materials. This one is the most subjective, since some people like their rainbow-colored assemblies, but I don’t.

Independent of what the kids say, 0.0005" is not clearance.

posts.name: Arshon Bozorgi
posts.cooked:
Clean CAD to me means using the least amount of hard dimensions as possible, while using the most sketch relations as possible. Still resulting in a fully defined sketch.

Also, the CAD should not break if dimensions are changed. The model should be responsive and using equations and global variables are a major plus.

posts.name: Wei
posts.cooked:
If I open a CAD file I want to be able to

Know what the part is. Please don’t label it “Funny Bar 1”. If I want to edit the roller on the intake then I’m not gonna look through “Part 1, Part 2” to find the roller and edit it. Good labelling of parts saves us time and headaches. (Seriously though, don’t name it funny bar 1).

Know what the part is. Please don’t label it “Funny Bar 1”. If I want to edit the roller on the intake then I’m not gonna look through “Part 1, Part 2” to find the roller and edit it. Good labelling of parts saves us time and headaches. (Seriously though, don’t name it funny bar 1).

Edit what I want without the whole thing breaking.

Edit what I want without the whole thing breaking.

Andrew_L:

Say it with me, kids:

Fully define your sketches

Know if there is a specific reason why something is a certain size etc. Just write it down on the working drawing or the part notes. Especially for us since we are in a country that uses metric, if you are making it a certain sized hole to fit an Imperial bolt or something put a dual dimension AND just make a note of it so we know why there’s one Imperial hole in the drawing when everything else is metric.

Know if there is a specific reason why something is a certain size etc. Just write it down on the working drawing or the part notes. Especially for us since we are in a country that uses metric, if you are making it a certain sized hole to fit an Imperial bolt or something put a dual dimension AND just make a note of it so we know why there’s one Imperial hole in the drawing when everything else is metric.

Have sensible working drawings. I want to be able to see what I need to do clearly, I want your name on it in case I have issues and I want to know what part I’m making in case I need to refer back to the CAD.

Have sensible working drawings. I want to be able to see what I need to do clearly, I want your name on it in case I have issues and I want to know what part I’m making in case I need to refer back to the CAD.

Bit of a stretch but I’d love it if Inventor didn’t crash as much.

Bit of a stretch but I’d love it if Inventor didn’t crash as much.

Seriously though, Clean CAD isn’t hard to do. I consider Clean CAD to be CAD that you can give to someone else halfway through and they can keep working on it without an unreasonable amount of fuss. It doesn’t have to be perfect, just good. So long as it is cohesive and makes sense then I’m more than happy.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
franklima260:

you should be able to understand what the designer was thinking when creating the part.

“Chaos, suffering, and panic” is my favorite story to tell.

But yes. Much like clean code. Naming things well, keeping it organized in a way that communicates intent (not just functionality). That’s how you get an answer that’s as correct as you can get it today, and is as painless as possible to modify once the answer becomes incorrect.

Also fillet all the things.

posts.name: SndMndBdy
posts.cooked:
To me, one of the most important parts of making clean CAD is that the sketch constraints capture the “essence” of your part.  For example, let’s say that you are trying to make a 2”x 2” square plate with a hole in the middle.  You could constrain that hole with a dimension such that it is 1” from the top and left edges, and that would get the job done.  But it is not “clean” because you’ve missed the point that the hole is supposed to be in the middle .  This problem inevitably manifests itself when you want to change your square to be 3”x3” and then your hole is no longer in the middle.  This will often mess up later steps in your sketch or in an assembly containing the part.

It’s tricky to learn to do this, but we try to impart the idea on our students every year.  The key thing we tell them is that you should ask yourself what is the core reason a certain feature is where is it, and then constrain it according to the answer to that question.

posts.name: Aidan
posts.cooked: Black and blue. Between the two I’ll always take The one that doesn’t break.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
Design is driven by a master sketch or sketches that capture the design intent of the part 1a. Use variables and equations to make the model ‘smart,’ especially when the same dimension is recycled in multiple sketches

Everything is fully defined with a minimum number of relations and dimensions 2a. A sketch or feature can be over-constrained without throwing an error, be wary of this

The model tree is sorted into intelligently-labeled and sorted folders

Features are ordered properly 4a. Fillets, drafts, chamfers, and other finishing features should be the last features, not interspersed in the history tree

Completely remaking a model to optimize its tree/equations/etc takes a lot less time than most think and is often a worth-while endeavor

This is my best example. The part is manufactured using 5 part molds with a total of 4 inserts, and then a 6th mold to over-mold everything together. But it took me maybe 5-6 drafts of the model to get to a point where everything updates reliably from master-sketch updates.

image 922×1913 191 KB

image 922×1913 191 KB

posts.name: Gdeaver
posts.cooked: My team consider any CAD I have not touched to be fairly clean.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Exploit symmetries whenever possible.  This minimizes the number of numerical constraints needed to determine your model, which is what makes it possible to modify in a sensible manner.  You can always break symmetries later if you need more degrees-of-freedom; it’s much harder to add a symmetry than it is to remove it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked:
From an FRC perspective, here’s what I like to see in CAD

Matches the robot, or the key robot building people know where it doesn’t match

First version is complete quickly

The people who edit it need to be able to quickly find what they need when making edits

Everything is fully constrained where it should be

Nothing is saved with errors (slows you down)

Don’t CAD things with a high Time:Value ratio (ex. zip ties, wires, rivets, most bolts)

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
I’m going to add to this:

Update the model to reflect changes that were made to the robot during build.

Update the model to reflect changes that were made to the robot during build.

include at least a rough representation of wiring and pneumatic tubing runs / lanes (at least as space reservations).

include at least a rough representation of wiring and pneumatic tubing runs / lanes (at least as space reservations).

Making mid-season upgrades is a lot easier if the CAD actually reflects these details.

posts.name: snichols
posts.cooked: I agree with a lot of the things that have already been said, but I’ll add one more: Mate things in the CAD the way they’ll actually be assembled. For example, anything that will be riveted or bolted should be mated by making the holes concentric. If a gusset will be riveted onto a piece of 2x1" and you mate the edges/corners, there’s a high likelihood students won’t notice that the holes don’t actually line up. Or maybe the holes line up at first, but then you edit something and the holes move but you don’t notice because the assembly looks unchanged.

posts.name: Daniel Wenbo
posts.cooked: Ok and thanks
